review.title: Searching for Topological Symmetry in Data Haystack
review.abstract: Finding interesting symmetrical topological structures in high-dimensional systems is an important problem in statistical machine learning. Limited amount of available high-dimensional data and its sensitivity to noise pose computational challenges to find symmetry. Our paper presents a new method to find local symmetries in a low-dimensional 2-D grid structure which is embedded in high-dimensional structure. To compute the symmetry in a grid structure, we introduce three legal grid moves (i) Commutation (ii) Cyclic Permutation (iii) Stabilization on sets of local grid squares, grid blocks. The three grid moves are legal transformations as they preserve the statistical distribution of hamming distances in each grid block. We propose and coin the term of grid symmetry of data on the 2-D data grid as the invariance of statistical distributions of hamming distance are preserved after a sequence of grid moves. We have computed and analyzed the grid symmetry of data on multivariate Gaussian distributions and Gamma distributions with noise.

sections.text: ar Xiv: 160 3.03 703v 1 [cs.L G] 11 Mar 2Finding interesting symmetrical topological structures in high-dimensional systems is an important problem in statistical machine learning. A limited amount of available high-dimensional data and their sensitivity to noise present computational challenges in finding symmetries. Our paper presents a new method for finding local symmetries in a low-dimensional 2-D grid structure embedded in a high-dimensional structure. To calculate the symmetry in a grid structure, we introduce three legal lattice moves (i) commutation (ii) cyclic permutation (iii) stabilization on groups of local lattice squares, lattice blocks. The three lattice moves are legal transformations, since they preserve the statistical distribution of hammer distances in each lattice block. We propose and predominate the notion of lateral symmetry as the data distribution from the structural D to the structural D.

sections.heading: 2 Low-Dimensional Topological Models
sections.text: Our method is general in nature and has characteristics other than the topological one. We code our data space as topological space because its high-dimensional characteristics (symmetry and connectivity) derive from its low-dimensional, local representations as in [Chen and Rong, 2010; Edelsbrunner, 2007; Carlsson, 2014].Topological invariants on Data ManifoldsComputing topological invariants in low-dimensional space are used for the study of symmetry in our data space. Homology groups are increasingly used in the calculation of invariants as their calculations and provide the important information about the shape of the object. The homology groups for the 2-D object are efficiently calculated by digitalization [Evako, 2006; Chen and Rong, 2004].

sections.heading: 4 The Ising Model on a 2-D Grid
sections.text: We formally propose a new Ising model of the data and calculate the statistical distribution of the Betti numbers as a small square space. We draw these parallels from the physical Ising model (Chakrabarti et al., 1996; Grimmett, 2010) and propose an analog data model. We then calculate a probable distribution of the Betti numbers configurations on the grid. This allows us to find the symmetrical distribution for the sampled grid according to the finite sequence of commutation, cyclic permutation and stabilization operations. We denote the 2 − D planar grid G = (g, N), where g is the small grid square and N the row of adjacent grid squares, as shown in Figure 7. The small red square grid is surrounded by the set of green squares.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental Results
sections.text: In this section, we set up a grid block with the size 1000 x 1000. We perform two scenarios of sampling the beti number. In the first case, the positions of the beti number within the grid are sampled using a mixture of two Gaussian distributions N (µ1, х1) and N (µ2, с2). In the second case, a 2-dimensional gamma distribution is selected to generate the position of the beti number. The grid block of the sampled beti number is divided into substance grid squares with the size 5 x 5. We perform grid movements, including commutation, cyclic permutation, stabilization on these local grid squares. After the transformations, we obtain the hammer spacing between the original grid squares and the corresponding transformed grid squares. With these synthetic data, we perform four types of tests, including (a) commutation, (b) cyclic permutation, (grid squares) of 9 and each chain of transformations.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We have proposed a new method to find symmetry, which is called lattice symmetry in data, by developing a new framework for the 2D lattice space. We have proposed three basic operations: commutation, cyclic permutation, and stabilization to determine symmetry. Statistical topology methods, i.e. the distribution of the beti number, are used as a feature in verifying symmetry in data. Our method of spatial distribution of beti numbers on 2D lattices can be encoded in constitutional neural network layers as a property of translational equivariance [Dieleman et al., 2016; Dieleman et al., 2015]. The method of data augmentation, as described in [Dieleman et al., 2016] for the formation of CNN's adaptations, is particularly consistent with our approach, as the random perturbations describe topological deformations well.

metadata.abstractText: Finding interesting symmetrical topological structures in high-dimensional systems is an important problem in statistical machine learning. Limited amount of available high-dimensional data and its sensitivity to noise pose computational challenges to find symmetry. Our paper presents a new method to find local symmetries in a low-dimensional 2-D grid structure which is embedded in high-dimensional structure. To compute the symmetry in a grid structure, we introduce three legal grid moves (i) Commutation (ii) Cyclic Permutation (iii) Stabilization on sets of local grid squares, grid blocks. The three grid moves are legal transformations as they preserve the statistical distribution of hamming distances in each grid block. We propose and coin the term of grid symmetry of data on the 2-D data grid as the invariance of statistical distributions of hamming distance are preserved after a sequence of grid moves. We have computed and analyzed the grid symmetry of data on multivariate Gaussian distributions and Gamma distributions with noise.
